text: um so again thank you so much for the wonderful introduction michael and thank you everyone for having me
here i know it's a tricky time for a lot of people at the moment um with covid and so on um so i'm really
grateful to have you all join my talk and i look forward to meeting many of you and i'm happy to answer any
questions or follow up individually as well and i'm really excited to share my work
so just to tell you a little bit about myself for those of you just joining in i'm an assistant cs professor at
virginia tech starting this coming fall but again as michael um so kindly introduced i decided to
spend some time as a postdoc here at stanford computer science as part of the nlp group and for my
current work at stanford i'm focusing on using nlp and statistics
to examine linguistic patterns related to escalation in police interactions captured through
body-worn cameras and for this project you know i work with wonderful people such as uh dan
jurassic from the cs and jennifer eberhard from the psych department here at stanford
for today's talk however i'm going to be focusing on my earlier work at uci where i recently finished my phd just last
year so i'll be excited to jump right in if you're like myself or my friends you
know um these days watching the news can be difficult and talking about it online even harder
especially when it's about politics or social issues and in fact uh we are like most people
here living in the us according to a survey conducted earlier just last year
you know almost half of americans have stopped talking about news related to politics with other people
and what's really interesting is that adults who are more engaged with political news
are more likely to have stopped discussing social or political issues with others
and this is a real problem because if we look back at history and how most democratic nations have
evolved you know people's ability to engage in democratic discourse or the ability to access and interpret
factual information and critically reflect and discuss important social issues
enables people to find common ground with each other despite having social or political
differences and this is crucial for democracies to function properly you know it's what keeps governments
accountable and brings society together however we all know that this is a real
challenge today about 67 percent of americans report to feeling confused
about basic facts around current events while 70 percent report to having seen political news that seems completely
made up and furthermore we have political extremism making it harder than ever for
people to talk to each other about important social topics and issues and on top of this
thanks to technology the way we access interpret and discuss information with
others have significantly changed over the years from watching televised news broadcast
typically in the evening more people now are coming across news whenever
and wherever in the course of doing something else another example is the display of
information in newspapers professional editors carefully curated content by category of topic and length
whereas today people can easily come across new content sandwiched between
advertisements videos or memes furthermore while discourse primarily occurred through face-to-face
interactions in the past today online conversations around current events are
often with strangers known only perhaps by username or profile picture in a thread of
thousands of other commenters and in fact on social media there are many design features that are
increasingly characterizing the conditions of how people come across and talk about current events take for
example the infinity scrolling of content on news feeds where attention is calibrated in
microseconds or hashtags that amplify the visibility of popular or trending social topics
and we also have affective comments or emotive buttons that induce us to emotionally react to
news content or even just observe how others do so so clearly the conditions in which
modern political discourse occurs have changed significantly and without really understanding how
these changes are affecting the way we perceive and talk about important social and political issues
online it will be impossible to improve the online environment as an avenue for democratic discourse so
what can we do you know as hci researchers we understand that the design of online
spaces affects how people engage with others and interpret content
in a similar vein in political communication researchers have shown that the digital public sphere or
the conditions in which online discourse occurs is said to be a key determinant of discourse quality
and as someone who kind of sits at the intersection between hci political communication it's hard not to
notice the strong interconnected link between these two fields now for example the conditions in which
online discourse occurs are made up of the various online design features that i've previously shown such
as hashtags affective comments emotive buttons and so on in other words the design of online
spaces shapes the conditions in which online discourse occurs second discourse quality is something
that we understand through how people talk with others and interpret content
so putting these two statements together in other words what both fields are saying is that the design of online
environments affects discourse quality but how this is precisely the question my
research focuses on as a scholar and researcher my work bridge is the field of hci and political
communication through which i examine and demonstrate how the current design of online
environments shape the quality of online democratic discourse at scale and in doing so i take two approaches
you know first i identify linguistic factors related to discourse quality for which i often use nlp machine
learning statistics as well as qualitative content analyses and second i demonstrate at scale
through empirical methods the direct impact of online design features on linguistic
behavior through large-scale surveys and experimental design and so far using these approaches i've
examined how online design impacts the nature of discussion on race class and issues related to gender
and and and in today's talk i'm going to demonstrate how political hashtags
as a common online design character affect the quality of online discourse around current events
using these two approaches you know first i'm going to show you how linguistic factors related to discourse quality
what words we use how we use it contribute to the divide in online conversations around political hashtags
and second i'll demonstrate how the presence versus absence of political hashtags and
social media news articles directly shapes the quality of discourse around social topics
related to race and gender issues so hashtags related to social issues or
political hashtags are pretty much an inseparable part of online discussions around current events
in fact you know designers and engineers have turned to political hashtags to increase participation in online
discussion around social issues typically by building systems that
classify rank and attach the top most popular hashtags to articles
based on the frequency of hashtags appearing in social media conversations in a similar vein journalists are also
using political hashtags as shown here to increase readership and to contextualize reporting
especially on social topics and this practice is particularly salient on
social media where news companies incorporate hashtags in the headlines or the text part of the social media
article in these short digestible previews and for this tactic to be effective it's
pretty common for news writers to capitalize on political hashtags that are known to have gone viral
and thus have brought resonance with current and potential readership
and according to columbia journalism review such practice is perceived as a good way to introduce a story or
perspective into the mainstream news cycle and a way to figure out what the public wants to discuss and
learn more about you know researchers too for the most part have generally taken a
positive view of how political hashtags shape online discourse emphasizing that political hashtags
inform debate challenge public perceptions around contested topics and enable personal storytelling across
discursive networks so engineers are using them journalists
and news companies are using them and researchers and scholars for the most part think political hashtags have
a positive influence on online public discourse then why are we extremely divided
across issues embodied by political hashtags for example one year after the metoo
movement reports now show that people's opinions have shifted more negatively against me to survivors and
according to polls people are more divided on issues surrounding sexual harassment
with the divide running primarily along partisan lines likewise the majority of americans have
an unfavorable view of black lives matter several years after it first came to national prominence
and again in light in light of uh recent events uh just last year um reactions to the black lives matter
hashtags have become even more complicated so again why are people becoming increasingly
polarized around important and substantive social issues embodied by political hashtags to answer
this question and given my interest in discourse behavior i first turned to
actual facebook comments surrounding me too articles published by three very politically distinct news outlets
to demonstrate how linguistic behavior contributes to this divide and perspectives around political hashtags
and here i focused on linguistic style and affect you know how people talk about issues related to the metoo hashtag
what kind of words they persistently used how they used it as well as the kind of topics they
focused on and finally i examined some of the biases or framing effects
that emerged from their linguistic behavior so from the three facebook news pages i
first identified all articles headlined with me too in the news post and from here i'm going to refer to news
articles published on facebook as news posts and i analyzed all the comments including replies on
each article and here are the key differences i found first comments from the far left and
alt-right news sites exhibited significantly greater use of profanity and words related to anger and
sex compared to those from the mainstream outlet for example outright comments contain nearly three
times the proportion of sexual words and five times the proportion of swear words compared to the new york times comments
far left comments contain nearly twice the proportion of such words compared to the comments from the mainstream outlet
and such difference in linguistic style especially in terms of negative affect is really important to
take into consideration because research shows that when people engage in heuristic processing
of political information on social media negative emotional words induce more negative conclusions on
what's being discussed what this means is that if you have a flood of social media news comments
charged with negative affect this can create a strong negativity bias towards the discussion topic
and this is exactly what was shown in the data these are tfidf results based on the
comments from the alt right and far left articles on me too and here i'm showing you the list of
keywords in the descending order of tf idf weight which i used as a proxy to examine
topical importance across commenters and as you can see both breitbart and democracy now
commenters are topically focused on sex with frequent references to body parts
and not only were these commenters pretty similar in the kind of topics they focused on but they
were very similar in how they discuss these topics across breitbart comments um sex had the
highest tfidf weight which means that it was a major topic that was often brought up
and in these comments people often brought in strong prior beliefs or assumptions around the legitimate
legitimacy of victim status and sexual encounters which is why the word sex occurs a lot
for example uh one commenter says so you sleep around and then 20 or 30 years later decide that you
were harassed or made to have sex did any claim rape did they have a gun or knife held to their throats
how does one claim they were forced to have sex i'd just like to know across the far left comments people are
focused on race denoted in this key word color um and these commenters often argued
over which race or class should be included or excluded in the metoo narrative as you
can see in the following comment yes women of color and working-class
women are especially vulnerable but me too is primarily with regard to upper-class white women
so these are some distinct linguistic patterns showing you know what words people persistently
use how they use it what kind of topics they focus on in discussion of me too across
public politically different facebook news sources and it got me thinking what kind of
framing effects can emerge from such conversational behavior and framing effect is a form of
cognitive bias in which people react to a given choice in different ways depending on how the choice is presented
in social linguistic research there is a similar idea expressed by firth who argues
understanding how a word is characterized by its nearby words can reveal key linguistic context in which it is
discussed uh so based on this premise i used war to vek which is a simple neural network model
to quantify the semantic proximity uh between the word meet to and nearby
words that co-occur with it to understand the potential framing around how metoo is discussed
and i built three embedding models using the corpus of commons from the three new sources and found some key differences uh here
i'm showing the top 25 word embedding tokens most similar to the word metoo based on
cosine similarity values and the cosine values here are uh basically the
similarity of angles between each vectorized token and the word metoo uh ranging from one
denoting that they're identical to negative one uh meaning that they're kind of uh absolute polar opposites
and as you can see among the new york times facebook news comments v2 is semantically closest with tokens
such as hashtag group campaign you know words that are intuitively characterizing me
too as an online social movement or a hashtag campaign for breitbart me too had strong semantic
associations with and always whereas for the far left comments me too was
semantically closest with words associated with social economic status such as fame
money famous rich and perhaps even hollywood so taking these embedding results i
conducted i conducted a qualitative analysis of all the comments that included these
top embedding tokens and found that there was a strong in-group versus out-group dynamics
in rhetorical behavior that kind of reinforced biases around how michi was
framed and discussed for example breitbart comments portray
me to participants as and who always have manipulative sex and
to advance their careers exhibiting a form of outgroup derogation as shown in this quote
because metoo is about liars looking for profit and control it's always the quote-unquote powerful
male say name and as shown in this example counters often used
absolutist expressions such as always and the word always is a really interesting word in political dialogue
because it's a form of rhetoric when used often and persistently is harmful for constructive discourse
around moral and political issues that need to bridge a wide spectrum of opinions and perspectives
but throughout my analyses i found that alt-right commenters consistently use such expressions when
describing those associated with the metoo movement all left commenters on the other hand
exhibited strong in-group favoritism based on race and socio-economic status
commenters frequently argued over how women of color or low income deserved more attention
within the metoo movement or that rich and famous women were unfairly hijacking the metoo narrative
from those who are more racially um and socioeconomically privileged you know for example
um uh uh compter from the far left um uh
news source reads the brutal gang rape of racy taylor is not comparable to the alleged sexual
assaults that rich white women oftentimes previously endured for fame and money are fighting for in their new media
movements and as shown you know far left communists are make are making these
blanket statements around which group deserves more empathy while we have alt-right commenters uh
making sweeping assumptions about the definition of sexual harassment or the character of those who
are coming forth about their experience using the metoo hashtag you know in other words what we're
seeing from this work is a lot of linguistic behavior based on generalized expressions
that promote dominant viewpoints uh within the discussion circle while marginalizing minority
perspectives and again this is harmful for democratic discourse because it discourages
empathy and sharing which ultimately lowers the chance to find a commonality through
shared experiences as people despite having different political views
so by looking at linguistic factors related to discourse quality uh clearly we can see that you know
people's linguistic behavior what words they use how they use it what topics they focus on is reaffirming
divisions and perspectives around how political hashtags are consumed and understood
but this could be just part of the picture you know what if political hashtags themselves were part of the problem
you know to find out i conducted an online experiment to examine whether and how the presence
versus absence of political hashtags in news post shaped audience reaction
in the previous project i examined discussion quality across three politically distinct news sources
under one design condition which was social media news posts with hashtags
in the second part of this talk i'm going to talk about an experiment in which i vary the design condition
by examining both the presence and absence of political hashtags in news posts while
keeping the media bias of the new source constant so using qualtrics i designed an
experimental survey in which i randomly show each participant a news post either containing or excluding political
hashtags in the headline and the text portion of the news post the hashtag condition on the left as you
can see here was actually the version published by npr and for the control condition on the right i
excluded the hashtag in the post text as well as a phrase me to prompts in the
headline and for the experiment we used ford news post topically focused on me too
and four on black lives matter giving us a total of eight news articles originally published on the new york times and npr facebook pages
and the selection of the articles was primarily based on whether the intended message of the
article could be best preserved with just minimal modification of the headline and the text portion of the
news post regardless of whether there was a hashtag or not so for each news post there was a
control and a hashtag version as shown here but we wanted to take this a step further and add a
second experimental factor to reflect the reality of social media news articles that often contain
um affective positive negative comments so i decided to add positive
negative comments as a second factor uh giving us a two by three factorial design
and this resulted in a total of 48 news posts one of which was randomly shown in the
survey system uh to the survey participant who answered questions um and left a comment and reaction to
the one news post they saw in the survey so through this experiment i wanted to
find out whether and how the presence of political hashtags and news posts affected the way people perceive news
contents specifically in terms of both positive negative reactions for positive reaction i asked whether
participants found the topic of the news post was socially important and whether they wanted to know more about social issues
pertaining to the news post and in terms of negative reaction i asked participants whether they found
the news post partisan and whether they perceive the news content to be controversial
and to understand these positive and negative reactions as dependent outcomes we ask people to respond to each
corresponding statements as shown here using a 5.5 point agreement scale
and this is what we found when hashtags are included in news posts people perceive the news topic to be
significantly less socially important and are less motivated to know more about social issues
related to the news content and in terms of negative reaction people find news posts more partisan
when political hashtags are included and also find the news topic more controversial
and this got me thinking uh since prior research repeatedly shows that hyper partisanship
is linked with less motivation to engage with social issues and that the quality of democracy is
partly the extent to which people are engaged with politics through social issues i wanted to further examine whether this
negative perception associated with political hashtags was a mechanism
that drives that explains decreased motivation for positive engagement around hashtag news
content hence i conducted a path analysis which showed that indeed
when political hashtags are included in news posts participants find the hashtag news content more partisan
but this is also the reason why people perceive the news topic to be less
socially important as well as why they are less motivated less motivated to know more about social
issues related to the news post similarly political hashtags and news posts which
heightens people's perception that the news topic is controversial deters people from wanting to know more
about social issues related to the news content and in fact it's not just the politically
conservative but also the politically moderate participants who have strong partisan reactions to
news content with political hashtags using kernel density estimate i
visualize the distribution of responses towards the following statement the partisan undertone of this news post
is obvious across three political groups and the distribution of responses among
those who identified and surveyed as extremely liberal for both the hashtag and the control groups
are left skewed meaning in general these folks tend to regard news posts about gender and racial topics from our
experiment less partisan regardless of hashtag presence by contrast for the extremely
conservative the distributions are more right skewed meaning that these participants perceive news content
with or without hashtags as politically biased so you can imagine um who did the
political hashtags really affect in terms of partisan reactions towards news content
it was the participants who identified themselves as politically moderate
and among these politically moderate participants those who saw news posts with hashtags
perceive news posts as more partisan than those shown news posts without the hashtags um as illustrated in the shaded gap
between the blue and red distributions here and in fact this difference um and partisan reaction between the control
and the hashtag groups among the politically moderate uh was significant
uh with the medium effect size so uh political hashtags clearly affect how
people perceive news content both positively and negatively and in terms of
partisan reaction hashtags particularly affect those who consider consider themselves
politically moderate now let's take a look at how political hashtags affect the way people talk
uh specifically um i want to show you how political hashtags shape the language people use in their comments
in reaction to news posts that they saw in the survey first when hashtags were included in
news posts people use significantly more words associated with anger
fear and disgust and again if you recall from my earlier study we know that linguistic style and affect
especially negative affect can generate a strong negativity bias around what's being discussed
furthermore when hashtags were included people also used more language predominantly focused on the hashtag
itself drowning out any reference to the main subject matter of the news post for example what i'm showing you here
are the keywords listed in the descending order of pmi or pointwise mutual information scores
which i used as a proxy to measure topical focus and what you're seeing here is that when
the black lives matter hashtags are included in news posts people tend to use language that is
clearly focused on the hashtag itself by contrast those in the control group
who saw the same exact news article again identical news articles but without the black lives
matter hashtag use language that are topically focused on the actual subject matter of the news content
and let me show you some examples of what these comments from the survey respondents actually looked like
here these are identical news posts one version containing the hashtag based on the original news post and one
that has been modified to exclude the hashtag on the right and going forth i'm going to show you some results from
the content analyses of the comments written by politically moderate participants from both the control and
the hashtag groups at first in the hashtag group participants repeatedly mentioned the
hashtag without substantially engaging with relevant social issues as shown in this example and when such
discussion behavior is replicated on social media this can amplify how much one is exposed
to a constant yet substance-wise empty reiteration and assessment of the hashtag resulting
in linguistic behavior focused on the politics of the hashtag as shown here by contrast
comments from the control group showed that ironically the absence of the hashtags actually
promoted the core ideas and values of the hashtag that that was originally meant to
represent for example a commenter in the control group who saw the news article without the metoo hashtag recognizes the importance
of giving platform and voice um to survivors of sexual harassment on social media
and keeping track of these instances without them going unheard which is the essence of what metoo
intended to represent and such reactions from the control group are really different
from the commenters from the hashtag group who often question the credibility of the news
content for example by referring to the news article statistics
as a load of crap or that the figures on the news on the topic has been inflated
and as a result leading them to think that the article was fake by contrast reactions from the control
group were much more nuanced and subdued um for example commenters remarked my first
reaction is that these numbers are really high or i find the information non-biased frankly these numbers seem
low to me another politically moderate commentary the control group remark
i suspect that the numbers for men may be lower due to the stigma that men reporting sexual assault would be viewed
as weak so as you can see you know respondents from both the hashtag and the control
groups are reacting to the same details shown in the news post however the interpretation as well as
the language used to interpret the content are vastly different in fact commenters from the hashtag
group use more emotionally extreme expressions for example even those who seem to be in
favor of the hashtag movement use pretty aggressive language to convey support for the movement
another prominent difference which was uh really interesting to see in the analysis was the use of first person perspective
and how people grounded their arguments for example this is a news post that originally included the black lives
matter hashtag and here's the version where we removed it and when the hashtag was removed
people often preface their arguments in the first person and these comments that i'm about to
show you are redacted for the purposes of this presentation i think is these days should be
you know i think that the main problem i think it makes some good points i'm a firm believer that i think that
discussing and to me uh this is really fascinating
rhetorical behavior because in political communication the use of first-person perspective and
dialogue is pretty significant because it rhetorically anchors a discourse to the
present moment of conversation and it signals reflection of personal values into the reasoning behind one's
words and is an indication of cognitive processing as well as sense of authenticity which are factors
that are known to contribute to constructive social discussion behavior
contrast this with why don't all lives matter black lives absolutely matter black
lives matter is a crucial topic black lives matter so do white lives asian lives hispanic lives and as you
can see here the language in these comments is less reflective less personal and less open to
difference and instead the majority of comments are strong duck letter declarative statements that
repetitively pivot around the black lives matter hashtag which leaves no room for conversation uh
with people who might share different perspectives i remember in the first study i told you
when we repeat repetitively process a flood of negative uh content on social media where people
process things through mental shortcuts it creates a negativity bias
and turns people off and our research statistically confirms this
you know people who use facebook more often several times a day are significantly more turned off by
these hashtags compared to those who are on facebook once a week in other words repeated exposure to
political hashtags are turning people off as expressed by this one participant who uses facebook
several times a day and was shown a news post containing a hashtag honestly social media is generating
something akin to false positivity or inflated enthusiasm i am so sick of this i am very liberal i'm not racist or
anything but it's just too much if i see another post on the internet about someone being a strong woman
i'm gonna lose my mind no one is benefiting from this we are not really more informed there's less information and more of the
same opinions on the same side expressed in this reaction you know false positivity inflated enthusiasm
not feeling more informed and being turned off by the news is pretty much the sentiment that echoes
the reality of what most americans are feeling and experiencing in terms of online news consumption and political
discourse as i've mentioned in the very beginning of this talk and what's contributing to
this reaction is something seemingly simple yet pervasive as a political hashtag this is why we
need to examine the quality of online discourse in relation to online design features
and i make two arguments as to how we can do so you know first when we think about designing for better
online discourse we need to take passive consumers or non-users into consideration
and second we need to take not just functional but also intertextual aspects of design and i'll
break down what these two things mean first remember how i told you that scholars have generally taken a positive
view of how political hashtags shape the online public sphere while implicit in these studies
is the assumption that hashtag media is received in a manner aligned with the goals of the community
using the hashtags to promote or debate a particular social issue in the first place
however nearly all prior literature have focused on what i call hashtag producers
or those who explicitly use hashtags and posting online content and this is most likely because of the
common process of collecting data through api filtering of tweets or comments
that includes specific hashtags which makes pi research to focus predominantly on hashtag producers
and right now most research using social media data to understand the nature of conversations or discourse quality
around social topics are based on such methods and i want to argue that we need to rethink
and evaluate how our methodological approaches are kind of limiting the way we understand online discourse
and as a first step as shown in my work we need to take non-users or passive content consumers
into consideration because as demonstrated in my findings non-users or
those who are passively exposed to hashtag content may not actually perceive or engage in
similar ways to the hashtag producers and this is important especially
because to affect change in social discourse and public knowledge around political issues
it's important that we are able to mobilize a broader audience that goes beyond passionate enthusiasts
in other words impact needs to spread beyond those initially aligned with the movement
however my work shows that politically moderate respondents you know people in the middle are turned
off by political hashtags and in fact contrary to prior literature my finding shows that in the long run
uh political hashtags may impede critical conversations around social topics especially around social media news
content which are and will continue to be important public spheres of discourse
this brings me to my second point to design for better online discourse we need to take not just functional but
also intertextual aspects of design into consideration earlier i talked about engineers who
build systems using political hashtags as design features to increase participation and discussion quality
well most of these engineers are predominantly focused on the functional aspects of hashtags which
you know enable searchability uh based on the frequency in which hashtags appear across online
conversations which in other words are again putting an emphasis on hashtag producers
and overlooking non-users or passive content consumers furthermore the sole emphasis on
functional aspects of design runs the risk of overlooking the intertextual nature of design features
related to online discourse and let me explain what this means
intertextuality is a notion that text attains its meaning in relation to other texts and i'll
explain to you what this means using political hashtags as an example when a political hashtag
becomes popular or is in the process of becoming popular the hashtag will be used in various ways
through the written text of millions of networked users and in that process
because any kind of utterance including ones that contain hashtags is by nature dialogic which means that a
word's meaning and power depends on what has been previously said about it the hashtag evolves
and gains meaning in relation to other texts depending on how it has been used and what has been
said about it and this intertextuality allows hashtags to become
charged with an additional semiotic pool as we have seen in my work
and this is why when designing for better online discourse we need to think about the intertextual aspects of them
of online design features so uh as a recap we're facing this
problem where people's motivation and ability to engage in online discourse is negatively affected with the rise of
fake news misinformation and political extremism at the same time
we also face a challenge where the conditions of online discourse have been significantly changing over
the years yet so far the conventional approach to understanding the nature of online
discourse has focused on content producers while the connection between online design and discourse quality has
yet to be explored with depth to this end my work empirically examines
the relationship between online design and discourse quality through various mixed methods
and take non-users and passive content consumers into consideration
in doing so my goal is to provide a renewed understanding around how common
online design features shape discourse quality at scale and by deriving empirical insights
i aim to contribute to the theoretical implication of online deliberation and design
research by bridging the field of hci and political communication both through
methodological practice and theory and finally the way i see my research having impact is by informing better
design and engineering practices for industry partners that operate our social platforms
um and a goal here is to really take my findings as a conversation starter to build a serious
dialogue not just with tech companies but also with journalists policy makers and activists and hence i
envision my work to open up broader applications to other topical domains
which i can talk about in my future work if i have time um
by the way i'm recruiting phd students uh for my lab at virginia tech so if you're interested
or know berlin students please send them my way so i'll go through this very quickly so
as you can see from my work i'm someone who believes that with better understanding of online design we can increase our chances of improving
the quality of online discourse you know how we access interpret and talk about information with other people
and first my immediate line of research focuses on understanding and improving online
discourse quality at scale and here i'm really interested in identifying linguistic markers around
affective psychological and rhetorical patterns of speech that can better inform how we understand good
versus bad online discourse and the motivation here is based on the fact that in order to improve discourse
quality we need to first be able to distinguish apart what constitutes factual uh constructive perspective
taking from you know toxic divisive and misinforming linguistic behavior
but we need to do this in relation to online design and this will be done through
application of nlp deep learning uh on a repository of data collected through large-scale experiments
and for this part of the work i'm really looking to collaborate with industry partners especially on their efforts to reduce
toxicity on their platforms
skip and second i'm really excited to examine um how audio visual cues you know such as
images tone voice facial expressions captured in various sources of data from both on
and offline interactions can be used to better understand how people talk to each other in various
contexts hence i'm looking forward to not only expanding the domain of interactions i'm
examining but also expanding into the different methodologies and approaches in which audio visual cues can be
analyzed in combination with with text and here the goal is to
understand how the various audio visual design cues are not only shaping the nature of
uh online interactions but how they might be perhaps linked with practical real-life consequences you
know from election results to fundraising impact job employment and so on uh and it is in
addition i will explore the different ways we can leverage audio visual cues and textual data together
to better understand and improve the way we talk to each other in offline context such as the work that
i'm currently doing looking at interactions captured through video footages of officers and drivers and traffic stops
so again i'm looking for creative ways to partner up with
industry and academic collaborators and look forward to working with bright students
so please don't hesitate to reach out to me yeah so this is end of my talk i'm so
glad i'm right under the time limit uh you've been a fantastic audience and i'm very happy to take questions
all right thank you so much um so panelists feel free to go ahead and just unmute yourselves and ask questions
in the meantime i just sent out a link to all the students if you'd like to submit
q a to the to the link we have a bunch of good questions already i'll start with one or two of those and then
we'll flip over to the panel uh so one question was asking
you found that conservatives found the articles about black lives matter and me too to be partisan regardless of hashtags and that
moderates found them more partisan when the hashtags were present and they pointed out that black lives matter and me too could um
they felt that they could generally be considered to be sort of liberally oriented topics or hashtags and they were wondering whether
there would be similar results for conservative hashtags yeah so me too and black lives matter
are generally regarded as uh hashtags pertaining to a liberal political perspective and
